bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

body.div1:
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES 9TH. JUDICIAL CIRCUIT, DISTRICT OF WASHINGTION, Northern Western DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of John McKinnon for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
To the Honorable C. H. Hanford, Judge of the Circuit Court of the United States, 9th Judicial Circuit, District of Washington, Western Division.
The petition of John McKinnon respectfully shows to your Honor:
1st. That the said petitioner is now and was at all times hereinafter alleged a citizen of the United States.
2nd. That the said petitioner is now a prisoner imprisoned and confined in the custody of the United States Marshall in and for the district of Washington in the County Jail of Spokane County, State of Washington.
3rd. That the cause or pretense of the restraint of the said petitioner according to the best of his knowledge and belief is that on or about the 25th day of August, 1895 in the District and County of Yale in the Province of British Columbia, one, Cornelius O'Keefe filed his complaint with Price Ellison a Magistrate in and for said district and county, charging that the said petitioner did on the 18th day of August, 1895, at or near Vernon in the County of Yale, Province of British Columbia, steal four neat cattle, property of him, the said Cornelius O'Keefe, which said complaint together with the depositions and evidence offered upon the hearing of said charge with the warrant of arrest and warrant of commitment therein, marked Exhibits A. B. C. and D. is as follows, and is hereby made a part of this petition.
Indictable Offences.
(A) Vide ss. 1 and 9.
Information and Complaint for an Indictable Offence. Canada. Province of British Columbia. District or County of Yale.
"Exhibit A"
THE INFORMATION and complaint of Cornelius O'Keefe of Okanogan taken twenty fourth day of August in the year of our Lord One Thousand Eight hundred and ninety five before the undersigned of her Majesty's Justice in and for the said District of County of Yale. who saith that John McKinnon on or about the 18th day of August instant at or near Vernon in the County aforesaid four neat cattle of the goods and chattles of the said Cornelisu O'Keefe did unlawfully did steal.
C. O'Keefe.
SWORN before me the day and year first above mentioned.
Price Ellison.
Indictable Offences.
(S) Section 590.
Deposition of a witness.
Canada
Province of British Columbia. County of Yale.
"Exhibit B"
The deposition of H. R. Parke of Vernon taken before the undersigned P. M. for the siad County of Yale this 24th day if August in the year 1895 at Vernon in the presence and hearing of John McKinnon who stands charged that upon or about the 18th day of August instant, at Vernon in the District of Yale for neat cattle of the goods and chattels of C. O'Keefe unlawfully did steal.
Harold R. Parke, sworn, saith:
I am Provincial Constable residing at the City of Vernon.
I produce a Hide-- On the evening of the twenty-third of August instant I s w a portion of a hide projecting from under John McKinnon's stable, the accused. I told Charles Emerson of the hide being there.
The following morning Charles Emerson brought me a piece of paper with a drawing of the brand which he said was on the hide I had told him about. I thought that it was Mrs. O'Keefe's brand and told him to take O'Keefe with him to see the hide. A short time afterwards he, Charles Emerson and O'Keefe returned bringing the hide produced with them (Exhibit A). Mr. O'Keefe identified the brand on the hide produced as his brand, Mr. O'Keefe then laid an information against John McKinnon and I arrested the accused on the twenty fourth of August instant. After the arrest I searched under McKinnon's stables and found two more hides. The hide about to be produced is a reddish colored hide -- he ear cut off -- The hide produced ("Exhibit B") I took out from under the accused stables on the afternoon of the 24th day of August instant- this hide has an indistinct brand on the left ribs resempling Mr. O'Keefe's brand -- after that, still on the 24th day of August instant, I went to the slaughter house where McKinnon, the accused keeps his hides, and found one black hide branded with a triangle on the left hip high up near the back bone, the top of the left ear was cut off. I also found a small roan hide in the same place with no brand on it that I could see, I also found a large red and white hide with the ears cut off and left leg cutt off. These last mentioned hides are now in my possession. On the 24th of August I also found in a cutter in the shed of
McKinnons a black calf without brand and head cut off -- I could discover no brands on the hides mentioned with the leg cut off.
Cross examined by Mr. Culey.
The brand on ("Exhibit B") resemples this is on the left ribs -- I believe this is a brand. When I saw a hide projecting from under the stable I was climbing over the fence and not more than ten feet way-- the floor of the stable was about two feet from the ground. That side was hence all open.
From what I knew of Charles Emerson's occupation I told him of the hide being in the stables.
It was about six o'clock in the evening when I saw the hide. -- about an hour or an hour and one-half afterwards I told Emerson. Charles Emerson told me that he was a detective. He has no done detective wrok for me before.
I have not got the paper emerson showed me. I never had it in my possession. The hide (Exhibit A) when I saw it might have been eight or ten days killed. The reason I told Emerson of the projecting hide was that there was a reward of $500. offered for convictions of cattle stealing. I did not wish to work for a reward as I am paid by the Government for my work.
I did not notice any other brands besides the one mentioned, on the black hide found at the slaughter house. I think I have seen Charles Emerson around here three or four months.
By the Bench.
The front of the stable is level with the ground and the side the manure heap fills up, the third side is blocked up by a vehicle shed and the side where I saw the hide projecting is about eighteen inches from the Govement fence.
the Government fence separates the building from the Gaul and Government Building.
During the last week I have croseed the fence three times a day. I always cross that way when I want to get meals for prisoners.
This place is in full view of any one crossing the fence but one cannot see anything under the stable without getting down and looking.
Sometimes for months I never cross at all. The fence is so close to the stables that anyone could see nothing under the stable without squeezing between the fence and building and getting down to look.
When I first saw the hide the greater porion was under the stable and the rest looked as if it had been pulled out by a dog.
When I first spoke to Charles Emerson I intended to continue the investifation myself. I used Emerson as a means.
I dont know of my own knowledge that the hide brought by Mr? O'Keefe and Emerson on Saturday to me was the same hide I saw on Friday morning.
I have seen Charles Emerson behind the Counter in Shooke's fruit store apparently working. I dont know of any other occupation.
H.R.Parke.
Charles Emerson, sworn saith: I am a Lathier.
Last Friday Mr. Parke informed me of a hide being under McKinnon's stables he said I might look after it. I told him I would. About nine o'clock that night I went to McKinnons stable I found the hide, (Exhibit A) there under the stable. The side of the stable facing the fence is open from the ground. The fence is about two feet from the stables. The fence is over four feet high. The hide was under the stable all but one corner. I would not have noticed it if I had not bee looking for it. I pulled the hide out and started toward the sidewalk with it in my hand In the morning of the 24th instant I examined the hide. after I scraped off the hair I found a brand on it similar to the There was an ear mark one ear was split. The other ear was not on the hide. I left the hide in the brush behind the victoria stable about five hours afterwards I took Mr. O'Keefe to see it. It was in the same place where I had left it. I showed it to Mr. O'Keefe. He said he would bring his rig and take the hide to the Jout House. He did so. I saw the hide again on the 24th and again on the 25th. I brought an hide into court this morning.
Const. Parke and myself found some more hides in a shed at McKinnons slaughter house between Vernon and Okanogah Lake. We fon three hides. I found a brand on the Balck hide it was a triangle The second hide was a roan hide. Could see not brand on it. The third hide was a red and white. Could not see any brand or Marks on it. These hides were sent to the Government house in an express wagon. When I showed Mr. O'Keefe the hide exhibit A he said it was his brand on it.
xd. When parke met me, he said good night. Then he said there was a hide under McKinnons stables. He said it might
pay me to look after it. I asked him whereabouts was under the stable. He told me that it was near the southwest corner. It was between half past six and seven or later. After I left Parke I walked around town. I was in Hurks Barber shop part of the time. I did not say anything to Murk about what Parke had told me. I have been staying at Murks during the past week. I was also in Davidsons fruit store and was about the street the rest of the time until nine o'clock. It was dark at 9 o'clock just after Parke informed me I walked past the place and saw that the hide was there. When I went at nine o'clock for the hide I left it half way between the sidewalk and McKinnons shop. I wnet to the side- walk as I saw a man there watching me. it was Mr. Birnie. He asked me what I was doing there. I told him that I was taking a hide out of there. I intended taking the hide to the brush. I was scared the man on the sidewalk might say something about it. It was old Mr. Birnie-- after I spoke with Birnie I went back to the hide and took it to the brush. I did not meet anyone else. I did not tell anyone else that night what I had been doing. the hide was not tied up. I saw Mr. Haron that night. he is night watchman. I told him about the hide early Saturday morning. I told him about taking the hide and asked him to come and see it after daylight. I did not tell him what brand was on it as I had not seen it there. I told him I had not seen it there. I told him that I had left it in the brush. Last a Wednesday night I slept either at Murks or my own shack. I think I slept at Murks on Tuesday night. I remember now I slept at Murks up to Friday night. I know a Half Breed named Frank Pete. I saw him the say Smart was tried. in the afternoon. it was nearly six. I saw him afterwards about eight o'clock, he called me out of Davidsons. He was riding, he wanted me on business he told me that there was counterfeit money among the six here. He said he would be in Friday nights again. I saw him about four
o'clock on Friday. I am a detective. I have had experience on one occasion. I have done detective work in the state before. I joined the detective association. I have been in Vernon two years. I have worked for Mr. Crowell. I have worked in Kelowna and Enderby. I worked for Judge Spinks. I have had no permenent occupation during the two years. there has not been enough lathing. I do not know a siwash or half breed named Victor. I saw some siwashes on Friday night. The only one I saw at the Coral was Pete. There were some whitemen strolling around. I took a walk with a white man at the corral on Friday night. He left me with Pete, I saw Pete twice that day. I did not say anything to Pete or Victor or any siwash about the McKinnon business.
C. EMERSON.
